that partly follows its course.

42.  Much discussion has taken place upon the question,
whether each of the composite forms of Foraminifera, such
as an Orbitolite or Nummulite, is to be regarded as a <u>single</u>
<u>individual</u>, or as a <u>colony</u> or <u>cluster of individuals</u. All
occasion for this discussion would, I think, be removed by
the adoption of philosophical views as to what really constitutes
an individual, and as to the relationship between the parts
which, having a common origin in one generative act; are
multiplied by a process of gemmation. As I have elsewhere
endeavoured to show (Principles of Comparative Physiology Chap XI 
Sect. 1.), the entire product of every generative act, whether
developing itself into a body of high organisation, distinguished
by the structural differentiation of its parts, or evolving itself
as an almost homogeneous aggregate of equal and similar
segments, must be regarded <s>[?]</s> as homologically the same;
<s>one organism</s>; and the essential difference between the two, as
living beings, lies in the <u>functional</u> relations of their respective
parts. For whilst in the former there is so close as <u>interdependence</u>
